Vorkath was a dragon featured in the Fort Forinthry quest series, lying dead beneath the ice of Ungael.[1][2] First mentioned in the Dead and Buried quest, its corpse appears in the subsequent Ancient Awakening quest where the Mahjarrat Zemouregal raises it from the dead into his servitude.[3]

On 20 November 2023 Vorkath was released as part of the Zemouregal & Vorkath boss encounter with the Battle of Forinthry quest.

History[edit | edit source]

Creation[edit | edit source]

Ages ago, the dragon later known as Vorkath was created by the Dragonkin Zorgoth with the intention of unleashing him upon the human population of Gielinor. Although he was considered one of the finest dragons ever created and intended as the ultimate weapon against humanity, Zorgoth discovered that Vorkath was far too tame and docile, playing with humans and protecting them. Various attempts to punish Vorkath for his disobedience with various methods were generally met with failure due to his strength and willpower. Eventually, Zorgoth killed Vorkath in a rage, believing that it was better off dead than alive to him. Eventually, he discovered the black stone from Kerapac's notes, realising that it could enforce compliance in the dead.

Zorgoth proceeded to cut out Vorkath's heart and replace it with a black stone heart, which revived Vorkath. This caused Vorkath's soul to remain in its now-decaying husk, unable to move on to the afterlife. At the same time, to ensure that Vorkath would follow his will, Zorgoth focused on making Vorkath hate humanity, which he deemed mildly successful after killing a human in front of the dragon. Despite this, he had already given up with Vorkath, and as he was too large to be moved to the Dragonkin Tomb underneath Forinthry, he put it on display in one of Ungael's towers instead.

At some point, the Fremennik were aware of Vorkath, calling it more ferocious than Elvarg, and they refused to approach the island out of fear for its considerable reputation, even though the dragon was mostly dead by this time.

Age of Chaos[edit | edit source]

After the Zamorakian Civil War ended, Zemouregal began to make plans to re-attempt conquering the Kingdom of Misthalin. The kingdom, with the help of the adventurer, managed to reclaim a vale north-east of Varrock and establish Fort Forinthry. Zemouregal then began searching for a power to destroy the fort and, eventually, learned of Ungael and Vorkath in the tomb. He immediately set off to the island to claim Vorkath before Moia could do so, still holding a grudge against her for taking a chunk of his power away. After delaying the adventurer with his undead army, he manages to raise Vorkath from the dead and together they started to fly back to the mainland. It is implied that Vorkath attempted to resist the attempt but was somewhat unsuccessful in doing so.[4]

Vorkath would later accompany its master to besiege Fort Forinthry. It used its dragon breath to raze the entire western section of the fort before it confronted the adventurer. During the battle, as the adventurer and the Raptor damaged Vorkath, it periodically turned on Zemouregal, a sign that his grip over the dragon was weakening. Eventually, after taking too much damage, Vorkath fled, abandoning its master and it was not spotted again during the battle.

Finding peace[edit | edit source]

The following takes place during Requiem for a Dragon.

Following Vorkath's departure from the mainland, it returned to Ungael to rest. Aster, worried that Vorkath could return, told the adventurer to figure out where it was and possibly put an end to it if necessary. The adventurer returned to Ungael and found that Moia had sent Zamorakian scouts to explore the area, and soon discovered Vorkath. Despite their previous fight, the adventurer knew that Vorkath had been forced to do so, and slowly gained its trust. They then tried to bring its soul to Um, but found themselves unable to. After investigating everything they could, they returned to Zemouregal, believing that he had warped its soul. However, Zemouregal himself stated that he was not responsible, and had likewise sensed the "rot" in Vorkath and claimed that if he had known how deep it was, he would have not bothered to enthrall him.

The adventurer then went to Death, who revealed that Rasial might have had an ancient artefact which could fulfil the purpose of restoring Vorkath's soul. As Rasial was busy reforming his body following his defeat to the adventurer, they sought out the Tree of Balance, who knew of a damaged artefact at the Memorial to Guthix. Once they restored the artefact, they set up a soulfarer ritual in both Um and Ungael to properly send Vorkath's soul to the afterlife.

During the ritual, Vengeance and a reanimated Bilrach arrived with a mysterious artefact to drain the dark power in Vorkath's soul. The adventurer attempted to intercept with the ritual, but Bilrach successfully completed his first, seemingly killing Vorkath's soul for good. The adventurer dejectedly returned to Um and told Death of the battle. Luckily, Vorkath's soul had just barely survived Bilrach's assault, and the adventurer's ritual successfully allowed it to arrive in Um, finally being at peace after thousands of years.

  • update 9 October 2023 (Update):

Trivia[edit | edit source]

  • In Old School RuneScape, Vorkath was first introduced in 2018 as the boss monster of Dragon Slayer II. There, Vorkath is missing his front left leg, whereas his RuneScape counterpart is not. Technical and time constraints meant existing four-legged dragon animations from Astellarn were reused, instead of creating new animations for a three-legged dragon.[5][6]
  • "Vorkath" in the dragonkin language translates to "failure".[7] Other rough translations include "pathetic failure/weakling/runt".
  • Vorkath is the first dragon in RuneScape whose dragonfire does not have 100% accuracy and is additionally affected by most defensive abilities.
  • When petting Vorkath in the City of Um after completing the Requiem for a Dragon quest, it is possible to receive the message "Behold, dog!", accompanied by an animation of hearts floating over Vorkath. This is possibly a reference to a meme surrounding the game Elden Ring.[8]

References[edit | edit source]

  1. ^ Overseer Siv, "Dead and Buried", RuneScape. "The Fremennik call it Ungael. We steer well clear of that island. It's rumoured to be guarded by a ferocious dragon. More powerful even than Elvarg of Crandor."
  2. ^ Player character, "Dead and Buried", RuneScape. "It doesn't look like a dragon I've ever seen before. I imagine, based on the age of this tomb, that this dragon could have been killed by now, or at least died of old age."
  3. ^ The Raptor, "Dead and Buried", RuneScape. "Dead or not. Let's not forget Zemouregal uses necromancy. Might be his intent. To raise it."
  4. ^ Vorki, RuneScape. "I refuse to be a puppet aga-"
  5. ^ Mod Dragon. "Vorkath: Battle of Forinthry, the latest update in the Season of Necromancy!." YouTube video. 15 November 2023.
  6. ^ Mod Doom. Did Jagex forget that Vorkath only has 3 legs?. Reddit. 3 May 2024. (Archived from the original on 3 May 2024.)
  7. ^ Archivist (Ungael), "Ancient Awakening", RuneScape. "He was our greatest 'Vorkath'. Our greatest failure."
  8. ^ Issy van der Velde. Elden Ring Players Debate Dog Meme Origins. TheGamer. 12 November 2022. (Archived from the original on 23 April 2024.) "Behold, dog! Every Elden Ring player has seen dozens of these messages, especially those of us who were around right when the game first launched."
